newsitem.title: JAPAN: Pioneer to launch first DVD car navigation system.
newsitem.headline: Pioneer to launch first DVD car navigation system.

text.p: Pioneer Electronic Corp. said Wednesday it would launch the world's first digital video disc car navigation system in Japan in June.
A company spokeswoman said DVD technology allows the new product to store seven to eight times as much information as conventional car navigation systems, which use CD-ROMs.
The product will have an 8-inch wide-screen liquid crystal display monitor, larger that any navigation system on the market, she said.
Pioneer also plans to sell the product in Europe and the United States but specific launch dates had yet to be decided, she said.
DVDs use a new laser technology that can store up to 4.7 gigabytes of data on each side of a disc, enough to record 133 minutes of film and sound.
The technology is expected eventually to replace CD-ROMs.

Pioneer said it would launch two models of the DVD car navigation system -- one that responds to voices, costing 230,000 yen ($1,840), and another without a voice control system costing 198,000 yen ($1,584).
The television monitor comes separately and will cost 178,000 yen ($1,424).
